Unstable pressure and u-equilibrium states for partially hyperbolic diffeomorphsims

Huyi Hu, Weisheng Wu and Yujun Zhu hhu@math.msu.edu Department of Mathematics, Southern University of Science and technology of China, Shenzhen, P. R. China111permenant addrss: Department of Mathematics, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA, huhy@sustc.edu.cn Department of Applied Mathematics, College of Science, China Agricultural University, Beijing, 100083, P. R. China wuweisheng@cau.edu.cn School of Mathematical Sciences, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, P. R. China yjzhu@xmu.edu.cn
Abstract.

Unstable pressure and u-equilibrium states are introduced and investigated for a partially hyperbolic diffeomorphsim f𝑓f. We define the u-pressure Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) of f𝑓f at a continuous function φ𝜑\varphi via the dynamics of f𝑓f on local unstable leaves. A variational principle for unstable pressure Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi), which states that Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) is the supremum of the sum of the unstable entropy and the integral of φ𝜑\varphi taken over all invariant measures, is obtained. U-equilibrium states at which the supremum in the variational principle attains and their relation to Gibbs u-states are studied. Differentiability properties of unstable pressure, such as tangent functionals, Gateaux differentiability and Fréchet differentiability and their relations to u-equilibrium states, are also considered.

Key words and phrases:
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification:

0. Introduction

Entropy and pressure are important invariants in the study of dynamical systems and ergodic theory. Entropies, including topological entropy and measure-theoretic entropy, are measurements of complexity of the orbit structure of the system from different points of view. As a generalization of entropy, the concept of pressure was introduced by Ruelle [15] and studied in the general case in Walters [16]. In fact, the theory of pressure and its related topics, such as Gibbs measures and equilibrium states, are the main constituent components of the mathematical statistical mechanics.

Let f𝑓f be a C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha}-diffeomorphism on a closed Riemannian manifold M𝑀M where α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. The well-known entropy formula in [11] shows that if μ𝜇\mu is an SRB measure, then the corresponding metric entropy hμ​(f)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓h_{\mu}(f) is the integration of the summation of the positive Lyapunov exponents. It tells us that positive exponents have contribution to the metric entropy. In particular, when f𝑓f is uniformly hyperbolic, both of the metric entropy and topological entropy are caused by the dynamics on the unstable foliations. However, when f𝑓f is (uniformly) partially hyperbolic, things become delicate. The presence of the center direction makes the dynamics much more complicated.

Recent years, the entropy theory for partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms are increasingly investigated. We can see the progress in this research topic in [7], [19], [20], [6], etc. In particular, for any C1superscript𝐶1C^{1}-partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism f𝑓f, Hu, Hua and Wu [6] introduce the definitions of unstable metric entropy hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) for any invariant measure μ𝜇\mu and unstable topological entropy htopu​(f)superscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f). Precisely, hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) is defined by using Hμ​(⋁i=0n−1f−i​α|η)subscript𝐻𝜇conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscript𝑓𝑖𝛼𝜂H_{\mu}(\bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1}f^{-i}\alpha|\eta), where α𝛼\alpha is a finite measurable partition, and η𝜂\eta is a measurable partition subordinate to unstable manifolds that can be obtained by refining a finite partition into pieces of unstable leaves; htopu​(f)superscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f) is defined by the topological entropy of f𝑓f on local unstable manifolds. Similar to that in the classical entropy theory, the corresponding versions of Shannon-McMillan-Breiman theorem and local entropy formula for hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f), and the variational principle relating hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) and htopu​(f)superscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f) are given. The main feature of these unstable entropies is to rule out the complexity caused by the center directions and focus on that caused by the unstable directions. In fact, hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) is equal to hμ​(f,ξ):=Hμ​(ξ|f​ξ)assignsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑓𝜉subscript𝐻𝜇conditional𝜉𝑓𝜉h_{\mu}(f,\xi):=H_{\mu}(\xi|f\xi) (where ξ𝜉\xi is an increasing partition subordinate to the unstable leaves) which was introduced by Ledrappier and Young [11]. Comparing the above two types of definition for the unstable metric entropy, we can see that the former one is more natural and easy-to-understand than the latter one.

The main purpose of this paper is to introduce unstable topological pressure Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) for a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1}-partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M and any continuous function φ𝜑\varphi on M𝑀M, obtain a variational principle for this pressure, and investigate the corresponding so-called u-equilibriums.

Similar to the way by which the unstable entropy is defined in [6], the unstable pressure Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) is defined via the information of the potential φ𝜑\varphi as iterating f𝑓f on local unstable leaves (see Definition 1.3). It is well known that the variational principle for the classical pressure was first given by Ruelle [15] for the system with the expansiveness and specification assumptions and then was obtained by Walters [17] for the general case. It shows that

P​(f,φ)=sup{hμ​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ∈ℳf​(M)}𝑃𝑓𝜑supremumconditional-setsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀P(f,\varphi)=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M)\Big{\}}

where ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) is the set of all f𝑓f-invariant probability measures on M𝑀M. We will combine the elegant method in Walters [17] and the technique in Hu, Hua and Wu [6] to obtain the variational principle for unstable pressure (Theorem A), i.e., the equality as the above in which P​(f,φ)𝑃𝑓𝜑P(f,\varphi) and hμ​(f)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓h_{\mu}(f) are replaced by Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) and hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) respectively. In particular, if φ≡0𝜑0\varphi\equiv 0, then we get the variational principle for unstable entropy (Theorem D of [6]).

The measure at which the supremum attains in the variational principle for unstable pressure Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) is called a u-equilibrium state for f𝑓f at φ𝜑\varphi (see Definition 1.4). Some fundamental properties for the set of u-equilibrium states are considered (Theorem B). Among these properties, we show that there always exists a u-equilibrium state for a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1}-partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism, in contrast to the case for the classical equilibrium state. This is essentially due to the upper semi-continuity of the unstable entropy map μ↦hμu​(f)maps-to𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓\mu\mapsto h^{u}_{\mu}(f). For particular potential φu=−log∥Df|Eu∥\varphi^{u}=-\log\|Df|_{E^{u}}\|, we relate the u-equilibrium states at φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u} to the Gibbs u-states of f𝑓f (Theorem C). In [17] and [18], some properties about the classical pressure and equilibrium states were investigated. We can consider the corresponding properties for unstable pressure and u-equilibrium states. We show that unstable pressure determines invariant measures (Theorem D) and there is a close relation between u-equilibrium states and tangent functionals (Theorem E). To study the uniqueness of u-equilibrium state, we define two types, Gateaux type and Frechét type, of differentiability of unstable pressure of f𝑓f at φ𝜑\varphi, and obtain several properties of them (Theorems F and G).

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 1, we give the definitions of unstable pressure and u-equilibrium state, and formulate the main results. We provide some properties of unstable pressure in Section 2. Section 3 is for the proof of the variational principle of unstable pressure. In Section 4 and 5, we consider the properties of u-equilibrium states and study how does the unstable pressure determine invariant measures. In Section 6, differentiability properties of unstable pressure are investigated.

1. Definitions and statements of results

and

∥Dxf|Exs∥<1 and ∥Dxf−1|Exu∥<1,\|D_{x}f|_{E^{s}_{x}}\|<1\ \ \ \text{\ and\ \ \ \ }\|D_{x}f^{-1}|_{E^{u}_{x}}\|<1,

for some suitable Riemannian metric on M𝑀M. The stable distribution Essuperscript𝐸𝑠E^{s} and unstable distribution Eusuperscript𝐸𝑢E^{u} are integrable to the stable and unstable foliations Wssuperscript𝑊𝑠W^{s} and Wusuperscript𝑊𝑢W^{u} respectively such that T​Ws=Es𝑇superscript𝑊𝑠superscript𝐸𝑠TW^{s}=E^{s} and T​Wu=Eu𝑇superscript𝑊𝑢superscript𝐸𝑢TW^{u}=E^{u} (cf. [5]).

In this paper we always assume that f𝑓f is a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1}-partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism of M𝑀M, and μ𝜇\mu is an f𝑓f-invariant probability measure. The notion of unstable metric entropy of μ𝜇\mu with respect to f𝑓f is introduced in [6], using a type of measurable partitions consisting of local unstable leaves that can be obtained by refining a finite partition into pieces of unstable leaves. We recall the construction of such measurable partitions and the definition of unstable metric entropy as follows. To begin with, we recall some standard notations and classical results on measurable partitions.

Definition 1.1.

The conditional entropy of f𝑓f with respect to a measurable partition α𝛼\alpha given η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u} is defined as

The following theorem is one of the main results in [6] (cf. Theorem A and Corollary A.2 therein).

Theorem 1.2.

(Cf. [6]) For any α∈𝒫𝛼𝒫\alpha\in{\mathcal{P}} and η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u},

Unstable metric entropy is closely related to the entropy introduced by Ledrappier and Young ([11]). Suppose that f𝑓f is C1+α​(α>0)superscript𝐶1𝛼𝛼0C^{1+\alpha}(\alpha>0) and μ𝜇\mu is ergodic. Recall a hierarchy of metric entropies hμ​(f,ξi):=Hμ​(ξi|f​ξi)assignsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑓subscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝐻𝜇conditionalsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑓subscript𝜉𝑖h_{\mu}(f,\xi_{i}):=H_{\mu}(\xi_{i}|f\xi_{i}) introduced by Ledrappier and Young in [11], where i=1,⋯,u~𝑖1⋯~𝑢i=1,\cdots,\tilde{u}, and u~~𝑢\tilde{u} is the number of distinct positive Lyapunov exponents. For each i𝑖i, ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i} is an increasing partition subordinate to the i𝑖ith level of the unstable leaves W(i)superscript𝑊𝑖W^{(i)}, and is a generator. It is proved there that hμ​(f,ξu~)=hμ​(f)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓subscript𝜉~𝑢subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓h_{\mu}(f,\xi_{\tilde{u}})=h_{\mu}(f), the metric entropy of μ𝜇\mu. If there are u​(1≤u≤u~)𝑢1𝑢~𝑢u(1\leq u\leq\tilde{u}) distinct Lyapunov exponents on unstable subbundle, then the u𝑢uth unstable foliation is exactly the unstable foliation of the partially hyperbolic system f𝑓f. It is shown in [6] that the unstable metric entropy hμu​(f)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓h_{\mu}^{u}(f) is identical to hμ​(f,ξu)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓subscript𝜉𝑢h_{\mu}(f,\xi_{u}) given by Ledrappier-Young. We remark that our definition of unstable metric entropy only requires f𝑓f to be C1superscript𝐶1C^{1}, while the definition and results by Ledrappier-Young requires the C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha}-regularity of f𝑓f.

Another notion introduced in [6] is the unstable topological entropy htopu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢top𝑓h^{u}_{\text{top}}(f). As a generalization, we define the unstable topological pressure associated with a potential φ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}) as follows. Denote by dusuperscript𝑑𝑢d^{u} the metric induced by the Riemannian structure on the unstable manifold and let dnu​(x,y)=max0≤j≤n−1⁡du​(fj​(x),fj​(y))subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑢𝑛𝑥𝑦subscript0𝑗𝑛1superscript𝑑𝑢superscript𝑓𝑗𝑥superscript𝑓𝑗𝑦d^{u}_{n}(x,y)=\max_{0\leq j\leq n-1}d^{u}(f^{j}(x),f^{j}(y)). Let Wu​(x,δ)superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿W^{u}(x,\delta) denote the open ball inside Wu​(x)superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥W^{u}(x) with center x𝑥x and radius δ𝛿\delta with respect to dusuperscript𝑑𝑢d^{u}. Let E𝐸E be a set of points in Wu​(x,δ)¯¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)} with pairwise dnusubscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑢𝑛d^{u}_{n}-distances at least ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We call E𝐸E an (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-separated subset of Wu​(x,δ)¯¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}. Put

Pu(f,φ,ϵ,n,x,δ):=sup{\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi,\epsilon,n,x,\delta):=\sup\{ ∑y∈Eexp((Snφ)(y))|\displaystyle\sum_{y\in E}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(y))|
E is an (n,ϵ) u-separated subset of Wu​(x,δ)¯}\displaystyle E\text{\ is an\ }(n,\epsilon)\text{\ u-separated subset of\ }\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}\}

where (Sn​φ)​(y)=∑i=0n−1φi​(y)subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscript𝜑𝑖𝑦(S_{n}\varphi)(y)=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}\varphi^{i}(y).

Definition 1.3.

We define unstable topological pressure of f𝑓f with respect to the potential φ𝜑\varphi on M𝑀M to be

Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi) :=limδ→0supx∈MPu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯),assignabsentsubscript→𝛿0subscriptsupremum𝑥𝑀superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\displaystyle:=\lim_{\delta\to 0}\sup_{x\in M}P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}),

where

Pu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}) :=limϵ→0lim supn→∞1n​log⁡Pu​(f,φ,ϵ,n,x,δ).assignabsentsubscript→italic-ϵ0subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛1𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑italic-ϵ𝑛𝑥𝛿\displaystyle:=\lim_{\epsilon\to 0}\limsup_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log P^{u}(f,\varphi,\epsilon,n,x,\delta).

Two alternative ways to define unstable topological pressure are by using (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-spanning sets and by using open covers. We discuss it in details in Section 2. Note that when φ=0𝜑0\varphi=0, the unstable topological pressure reduces to the unstable topological entropy.

Let ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) and ℳfe​(M)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M) denote the set of all f𝑓f-invariant and ergodic probability measures on M𝑀M respectively. Our first main result is the variational principle relating unstable topological pressure and unstable metric pressure, the sum of unstable metric entropy and integral of the potential.

Theorem A.

Let f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M be a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1} partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism. Then for any φ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}),

Pu​(f,φ)=sup{hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ∈ℳf​(M)}.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀P^{u}(f,\varphi)=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M)\Big{\}}.

Moreover,

Pu​(f,φ)=sup{hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ∈ℳfe​(M)}.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀P^{u}(f,\varphi)=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M)\Big{\}}.

As an immediate corollary, we recover the variational principle for unstable entropies, obtained in [6].

Corollary A.1.

Let f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M be a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1} partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism. Then

htopu​(f)=sup{hμu​(f):μ∈ℳf​(M)}.subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢top𝑓supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀h^{u}_{\text{top}}(f)=\sup\{h_{\mu}^{u}(f):\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M)\}.

Moreover,

htopu​(f)=sup{hνu​(f):ν∈ℳfe​(M)}.subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢top𝑓supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜈𝑢𝑓𝜈subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀h^{u}_{\text{top}}(f)=\sup\{h_{\nu}^{u}(f):\nu\in\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M)\}.

Let P​(f,φ)𝑃𝑓𝜑P(f,\varphi) be the classical topological pressure of f𝑓f associated to potential φ𝜑\varphi (cf. Chapter 9 in [17]). By the definition of Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi) and Theorem A, we have the following facts.

Corollary A.2.

Pu​(f,φ)≤P​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑃𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi)\leq P(f,\varphi).

If f𝑓f is C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha}, the equation holds if there is no positive Lyapunov exponent in the center direction at ν𝜈\nu-a.e. with respect to any ergodic measure ν𝜈\nu.

The variational principle Theorem A gives a natural way of selecting members of ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). The following concept of u-equilibrium state generalizes measure of maximal unstable entropy.

Definition 1.4.

Let φ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}). A member μ𝜇\mu of ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) is called a u-equilibrium state for φ𝜑\varphi if Pu​(f,φ)=hμu​(f)+∫φ​𝑑μsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓𝜑differential-d𝜇P^{u}(f,\varphi)=h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int\varphi d\mu. Let ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) denote the set of all u-equilibrium states for φ𝜑\varphi.

A measure of maximal unstable entropy is a u-equilibrium state for the potential 00. A significant result in [6] is that the unstable metric entropy function is upper semicontinuous (cf. Proposition 2.15 in [6] which is restated in Lemma 3.4 below). Therefore, a u-equilibrium state should always exist for partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms. Furthermore, ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) has the following nontrivial properties.

Theorem B.
  1. (1)

    ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) is convex.

  2. (2)

    ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) is nonempty and compact.

  3. (3)

    The extreme points of ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) are precisely the ergodic members of ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f).

  4. (4)

    If φ,ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi,\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}), and there exists c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R} such that φ−ψ−c𝜑𝜓𝑐\varphi-\psi-c belongs to the closure of the set {h∘f−h:h∈C​(M,ℝ)}conditional-setℎ𝑓ℎℎ𝐶𝑀ℝ\{h\circ f-h:h\in C(M,\mathbb{R})\} in C​(M,ℝ)𝐶𝑀ℝC(M,\mathbb{R}), then ℳφu​(M,f)=ℳψu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜓𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f)=\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\psi}(M,f).

Gibbs u-states form a special class of invariant probability measures on M𝑀M whose conditional measures along unstable leaves are absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure on the leaves (cf. [12], [2], see also p. 221 in [1]). In uniformly hyperbolic case, they correspond to Gibbs states, which are the equilibrium states associated to a potential defined by the Jacobian along unstable direction. If f:M→M:𝑓→𝑀𝑀f:M\to M is a C1superscript𝐶1C^{1} partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism, there is also a distinguished potential φu(x)=−log∥Df|Eu​(x)∥\varphi^{u}(x)=-\log\|Df|_{E^{u}(x)}\|. We relate the u-equilibrium states associated to φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u} to the Gibbs u-states of f𝑓f.

Theorem C.

Let f𝑓f be C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha} and μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). Then μ𝜇\mu is a Gibbs u-state of f𝑓f if and only if μ𝜇\mu is a u-equilibrium state of φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u}.

Corollary C.1.

If f𝑓f is C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha}, then Pu​(f,φu)=0superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓superscript𝜑𝑢0P^{u}(f,\varphi^{u})=0.

Corollary C.2.

There always exists a Gibbs u-state for any C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha} partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism.

Corollary C.2 which can be easily extended to the partially hyperbolic attractor case, recovers the existence result proved in [12].

It is well known that the (classical) topological pressure P​(f,⋅)𝑃𝑓⋅P(f,\cdot) determines the set ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) and the entropy hμ​(f)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓h_{\mu}(f) for all μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M), in the sense of Theorems 9.11 and 9.12 in [17]. We recall the precise meaning as follows. A finite signed measure on M𝑀M is a map μ:ℬ​(M)→ℝ:𝜇→ℬ𝑀ℝ\mu:\mathcal{B}(M)\to\mathbb{R} which is countably additive, where ℬ​(M)ℬ𝑀\mathcal{B}(M) is the σ𝜎\sigma-algebra of Borel subsets of M𝑀M. Then μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) if and only if ∫Mφ​𝑑μ≤P​(f,φ)subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝑃𝑓𝜑\int_{M}\varphi d\mu\leq P(f,\varphi) for ∀φ∈C​(M,ℝ).for-all𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\forall\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}). Moreover, hν​(f)=inf{P​(f,φ)−∫Mφ​𝑑ν:φ∈C​(M,ℝ)}subscriptℎ𝜈𝑓infimumconditional-set𝑃𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜈𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝh_{\nu}(f)=\inf\left\{P(f,\varphi)-\int_{M}\varphi d\nu:\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R})\right\} holds if and only if the entropy map μ↦hμ​(f)maps-to𝜇subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}(f) is upper semi-continuous at ν𝜈\nu. Rather surprisingly, the analogue holds for unstable pressure: the unstable topological pressure Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) which might be considered as a partial pressure of the system, also determines the set ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) and the entropy hμu​(f)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓h^{u}_{\mu}(f) for all μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). Moreover, we have a cleaner result since the unstable entropy map μ↦hμu​(f)maps-to𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓\mu\mapsto h^{u}_{\mu}(f) is always upper semi-continuous.

Theorem D.
  1. (1)

    Let μ:ℬ​(M)→ℝ:𝜇→ℬ𝑀ℝ\mu:\mathcal{B}(M)\to\mathbb{R} be a finite signed measure. Then μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) if and only if ∫Mφ​𝑑μ≤Pu​(f,φ)subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\int_{M}\varphi d\mu\leq P^{u}(f,\varphi), ∀φ∈C​(M,ℝ).for-all𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\forall\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}).

  2. (2)

    Let ν∈ℳf​(M)𝜈subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\nu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). Then

    hνu​(f)=inf{Pu​(f,φ)−∫Mφ​𝑑ν:φ∈C​(M,ℝ)}.superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜈𝑢𝑓infimumconditional-setsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜈𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝh_{\nu}^{u}(f)=\inf\left\{P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\int_{M}\varphi d\nu:\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R})\right\}.

As the existence of u-equilibrium state is guaranteed by the upper semicontinuity of the unstable entropy map, it is natural to ask when the u-equilibrium state is unique. This question is very subtle and already attracts a lot of interest in the case of the classical pressure. In this paper, we study the differentiability properties of the unstable pressure and their relations to the uniqueness of u-equilibrium state. Such an approach is developed in [18] for the classical pressure.

To start with, we define a notion of tangent functional to the convex function Pu​(f,⋅):C​(M,ℝ)→ℝ:superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅→𝐶𝑀ℝℝP^{u}(f,\cdot):C(M,\mathbb{R})\to\mathbb{R}, which is closely related to the u-equilibrium state. The (classical) tangent functional can be found in Definition 9.9 in [17].

Definition 1.5.

Let φ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}). A u-tangent functional to Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi is a finite signed measure μ:ℬ​(M)→ℝ:𝜇→ℬ𝑀ℝ\mu:\mathcal{B}(M)\to\mathbb{R} such that

Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)≥∫Mψ​𝑑μ,∀ψ∈C​(M,ℝ).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇for-all𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝP^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)\geq\int_{M}\psi d\mu,\quad\forall\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}).

Let tφu​(M,f)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f) denote the set of all u-tangent functionals to Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi.

For the classical tangent functional and equilibrium state, the equality ℳφ​(M,f)=tφ​(M,f)subscriptℳ𝜑𝑀𝑓subscript𝑡𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}_{\varphi}(M,f)=t_{\varphi}(M,f) holds under the assumption that μ↦hμ​(f)maps-to𝜇subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}(f) is upper semi-continuous at the members of tφ​(M,f)subscript𝑡𝜑𝑀𝑓t_{\varphi}(M,f) (cf. Theorem 9.15 in [17]). The assumption is unnecessary for the u-tangent functional:

Theorem E.

ℳφu​(M,f)=tφu​(M,f).subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f)=t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f).

In the following, we consider two types of differentiability of unstable pressure.

Definition 1.6.

The unstable topological pressure Pu​(f,⋅):C​(M,ℝ)→ℝ:superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅→𝐶𝑀ℝℝP^{u}(f,\cdot):C(M,\mathbb{R})\to\mathbb{R} is said to be Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if

limt→01t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ))subscript→𝑡01𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi))

exists for any ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}).

Theorem F.

Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if and only if there is a unique unstable tangent functional to Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi.

Combining Theorems E and F, we have

Corollary F.1.

Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if and only if there is a unique u-equilibrium state of φ𝜑\varphi.

Now we consider the Fréchet differentiability of unstable topological pressure.

Definition 1.7.

Pu​(f,⋅):C​(M,ℝ)→ℝ:superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅→𝐶𝑀ℝℝP^{u}(f,\cdot):C(M,\mathbb{R})\to\mathbb{R} is said to be Fréchet differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if ∃γ∈C​(M,ℝ)∗𝛾𝐶superscript𝑀ℝ\exists\gamma\in C(M,\mathbb{R})^{*} such that

limψ→0|Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)−γ​(ψ)|‖ψ‖=0.subscript→𝜓0superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝛾𝜓norm𝜓0\lim_{\psi\to 0}\frac{|P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\gamma(\psi)|}{\|\psi\|}=0.

Let μn→μ→subscript𝜇𝑛𝜇\mu_{n}\to\mu denote the convergence in weak∗ topology, and ‖μn−μ‖→0→normsubscript𝜇𝑛𝜇0\|\mu_{n}-\mu\|\to 0 the convergence in norm topology on ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). We have the following equivalent ways to describe Fréchet differentiability of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot).

Theorem G.

The following statements are mutually equivalent.

  1. (1)

    Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Fréchet differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi.

  2. (2)

    There is a measure μφ∈ℳf​(M)subscript𝜇𝜑subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu_{\varphi}\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) such that whenever (μn)⊂ℳf​(M)subscript𝜇𝑛subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀(\mu_{n})\subset\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) with hμnu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μn→Pu​(f,φ)→superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu_{n}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{n}\to P^{u}(f,\varphi) we have ‖μn−μφ‖→0→normsubscript𝜇𝑛subscript𝜇𝜑0\|\mu_{n}-\mu_{\varphi}\|\to 0 as n→∞.→𝑛n\to\infty.

  3. (3)

    tφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓t^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) consists of one member μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} and

    Pu​(f,φ)>sup{hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ​ is ergodic and ​μ≠μφ}.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇 is ergodic and 𝜇subscript𝜇𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi)>\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\text{\ is ergodic and\ }\mu\neq\mu_{\varphi}\Big{\}}.
  4. (4)

    tφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓t^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) consists of one member μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} and there is a weak∗ neighborhood V𝑉V of μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} such that

    hμφu​(f)>sup{hμu​(f):μ∈V​ is ergodic and ​μ≠μφ}.superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝜑𝑢𝑓supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓𝜇𝑉 is ergodic and 𝜇subscript𝜇𝜑h_{\mu_{\varphi}}^{u}(f)>\sup\{h_{\mu}^{u}(f):\mu\in V\text{\ is ergodic and\ }\mu\neq\mu_{\varphi}\}.
  5. (5)

    Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is affine on a neighborhood of φ.𝜑\varphi.

  6. (6)

    tφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓t^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) consists of one member μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} and sup{∥μ−μφ∥:μ∈tφ+ψu(M,f)}→0\sup\{\|\mu-\mu_{\varphi}\|:\mu\in t^{u}_{\varphi+\psi}(M,f)\}\to 0 as ψ→0.→𝜓0\psi\to 0.

  7. (7)

    tφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscript𝑡𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓t^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) consists of one member μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} and inf{∥μ−μφ∥:μ∈tφ+ψu(M,f)}→0\inf\{\|\mu-\mu_{\varphi}\|:\mu\in t^{u}_{\varphi+\psi}(M,f)\}\to 0 as ψ→0.→𝜓0\psi\to 0.

It follows that Fréchet differentiability of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) implies the uniqueness of u-equilibrium state. It is also clear that Fréchet differentiability of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is stronger than Gateaux differentiability of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot), either by the definitions or by Theorems F and G.

2. Unstable topological pressure

In this section, we redefine the unstable topological pressure via the spanning sets and open covers, and discuss its basic properties.

2.1. Definition using spanning sets

Recall that unstable topological pressure is defined in Definition 1.3 using (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-separated sets. We can also define unstable topological pressure by using (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-spanning sets as follows.

A set F⊂Wu​(x)𝐹superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥F\subset W^{u}(x) is called an (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-spanning set of Wu​(x,δ)¯¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)} if Wu​(x,δ)¯⊂⋃y∈FBnu​(y,ϵ)¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿subscript𝑦𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑢𝑛𝑦italic-ϵ\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}\subset\bigcup_{y\in F}B^{u}_{n}(y,\epsilon), where Bnu​(y,ϵ)={z∈Wu​(x):dnu​(y,z)≤ϵ}subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑢𝑛𝑦italic-ϵconditional-set𝑧superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑢𝑛𝑦𝑧italic-ϵB^{u}_{n}(y,\epsilon)=\{z\in W^{u}(x):d^{u}_{n}(y,z)\leq\epsilon\} is the (n,ϵ)𝑛italic-ϵ(n,\epsilon) u-Bowen ball around y𝑦y. Put

Qu(f,φ,ϵ,n,x,δ):=inf{\displaystyle Q^{u}(f,\varphi,\epsilon,n,x,\delta):=\inf\Big{\{} ∑x∈Fexp((Snφ)(x))|\displaystyle\sum_{x\in F}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(x))|
F is an (n,ϵ) u-spanning subset of Wu​(x,δ)¯}.\displaystyle F\text{\ is an\ }(n,\epsilon)\text{\ u-spanning subset of\ }\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}\Big{\}}.

Then in Definition 1.3 we can also define

Pu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯):=limϵ→0lim supn→∞1n​log⁡Qu​(f,φ,ϵ,n,x,δ).assignsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿subscript→italic-ϵ0subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛1𝑛superscript𝑄𝑢𝑓𝜑italic-ϵ𝑛𝑥𝛿P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}):=\lim_{\epsilon\to 0}\limsup_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log Q^{u}(f,\varphi,\epsilon,n,x,\delta).

It is standard to verify that these two definitions for Pu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}) coincide.

The following lemma is useful.

Lemma 2.1.

2.2. Definition using open covers

We proceed to define the unstable topological pressure by using open covers. Let 𝒞Msubscript𝒞𝑀\mathcal{C}_{M} denote the set of Borel covers of M𝑀M and 𝒞Mo⊂𝒞Msuperscriptsubscript𝒞𝑀𝑜subscript𝒞𝑀\mathcal{C}_{M}^{o}\subset\mathcal{C}_{M} the set of open covers of M𝑀M. Given 𝒰∈𝒞M𝒰subscript𝒞𝑀\mathcal{U}\in\mathcal{C}_{M}, denote 𝒰mn:=⋁i=mnf−i​𝒰assignsuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚𝑛superscript𝑓𝑖𝒰\mathcal{U}_{m}^{n}:=\bigvee_{i=m}^{n}f^{-i}\mathcal{U}. Put

pu​(f,φ,𝒰,n,x,δ):=inf{∑B∈𝒱supy∈B∩Wu​(x,δ)¯exp⁡((Sn​φ)​(y))|𝒱∈𝒞M,𝒱⪰𝒰0n−1}.assignsuperscript𝑝𝑢𝑓𝜑𝒰𝑛𝑥𝛿infimumconditional-setsubscript𝐵𝒱subscriptsupremum𝑦𝐵¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑦formulae-sequence𝒱subscript𝒞𝑀succeeds-or-equals𝒱superscriptsubscript𝒰0𝑛1p^{u}(f,\varphi,\mathcal{U},n,x,\delta):=\inf\Big{\{}\sum_{B\in\mathcal{V}}\sup_{y\in B\cap\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(y))|\mathcal{V}\in\mathcal{C}_{M},\mathcal{V}\succeq\ \mathcal{U}_{0}^{n-1}\Big{\}}.

If B∩Wu​(x,δ)¯=∅𝐵¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿B\cap\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}=\emptyset, we set supy∈B∩Wu​(x,δ)¯exp⁡((Sn​φ)​(y))=0subscriptsupremum𝑦𝐵¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑦0\sup_{y\in B\cap\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(y))=0.

Definition 2.2.

We define

P~u​(f,φ)superscript~𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\displaystyle\widetilde{P}^{u}(f,\varphi) :=limδ→0supx∈MP~u​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯),assignabsentsubscript→𝛿0subscriptsupremum𝑥𝑀superscript~𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\displaystyle:=\lim_{\delta\to 0}\sup_{x\in M}\widetilde{P}^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}),

where

P~u​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)superscript~𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\displaystyle\widetilde{P}^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}) :=sup𝒰∈𝒞Molim supn→∞1n​log⁡pu​(f,φ,𝒰,n,x,δ).assignabsentsubscriptsupremum𝒰superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑀𝑜subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛1𝑛superscript𝑝𝑢𝑓𝜑𝒰𝑛𝑥𝛿\displaystyle:=\sup_{\mathcal{U}\in\mathcal{C}_{M}^{o}}\limsup_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log p^{u}(f,\varphi,\mathcal{U},n,x,\delta).
Remark 2.3.

It is not clear whether the sequence log⁡pu​(f,φ,ϵ,n,x,δ)superscript𝑝𝑢𝑓𝜑italic-ϵ𝑛𝑥𝛿\log p^{u}(f,\varphi,\epsilon,n,x,\delta) is subadditive or not, so we have used lim suplimit-supremum\limsup in the definition above. This is one of the main difference from the case for classical topological pressure.

Observe that for δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 small enough, there exists C>1𝐶1C>1 such that for any x∈M𝑥𝑀x\in M,

(2.5) d​(y,z)≤du​(y,z)≤C​d​(y,z), for any ​y,z∈Wu​(x,δ)¯formulae-sequence𝑑𝑦𝑧superscript𝑑𝑢𝑦𝑧𝐶𝑑𝑦𝑧 for any 𝑦𝑧¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿d(y,z)\leq d^{u}(y,z)\leq Cd(y,z),\text{\ \ for any }y,z\in\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}

since M𝑀M is compact and Wusuperscript𝑊𝑢W^{u} is a continuous foliation. By arguments similar to the proof of Theorems 9.2 and 9.4 in [17], we can verify that Definitions 1.3 and 2.2 for unstable topological pressure coincide:

Proposition 2.4.

P~u​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)=Pu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)superscript~𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\widetilde{P}^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)})=P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)}). As a consequence,

P~u​(f,φ)=Pu​(f,φ).superscript~𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\widetilde{P}^{u}(f,\varphi)=P^{u}(f,\varphi).

2.3. Basic properties of unstable topological pressure

Here we list some properties of unstable topological pressure. The proof is straightforward by definition and hence is omitted.

Proposition 2.5.

If φ,ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi,\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}) with norm ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| and c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R}, then the following statements are true.

  1. (1)

    Pu​(f,0)=htopu​(f)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓0superscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓P^{u}(f,0)=h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f).

  2. (2)

    Pu​(f,φ+c)=Pu​(f,φ)+csuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑐superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑐P^{u}(f,\varphi+c)=P^{u}(f,\varphi)+c.

  3. (3)

    φ≤ψ𝜑𝜓\varphi\leq\psi implies Pu​(f,φ)≤Pu​(f,ψ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜓P^{u}(f,\varphi)\leq P^{u}(f,\psi). In particular, htopu​(f)+infφ≤Pu​(f,φ)≤htopu​(f)+supφsuperscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓infimum𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscriptsubscriptℎtop𝑢𝑓supremum𝜑h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f)+\inf\varphi\leq P^{u}(f,\varphi)\leq h_{\text{top}}^{u}(f)+\sup\varphi.

  4. (4)

    |Pu​(f,φ)−Pu​(f,ψ)|≤‖φ−ψ‖superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜓norm𝜑𝜓|P^{u}(f,\varphi)-P^{u}(f,\psi)|\leq\|\varphi-\psi\|.

  5. (5)

    Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is convex.

  6. (6)

    Pu​(f,φ+ψ∘f−ψ)=Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓𝑓𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi\circ f-\psi)=P^{u}(f,\varphi).

  7. (7)

    Pu​(f,φ+ψ)≤Pu​(f,φ)+Pu​(f,ψ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜓P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)\leq P^{u}(f,\varphi)+P^{u}(f,\psi).

  8. (8)

    Pu​(f,c​φ)≤c​Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝑐𝜑𝑐superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,c\varphi)\leq cP^{u}(f,\varphi) if c≥1𝑐1c\geq 1 and Pu​(f,c​φ)≥c​Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝑐𝜑𝑐superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,c\varphi)\geq cP^{u}(f,\varphi) if c≤1𝑐1c\leq 1.

  9. (9)

    |Pu​(f,φ)|≤Pu​(f,|φ|)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑|P^{u}(f,\varphi)|\leq P^{u}(f,|\varphi|).

3. The variational principle

3.1. Some properties of unstable metric entropy

In this subsection, we collect some important properties of unstable metric entropy proved in [6]. In particular, they will be used in the proof of variational principle (Theorem A) and in describing the set ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) in Theorem B.

Lemma 3.1.

(Corollary A.2 in [6]) hμu​(f)=hμ​(f,α|η)=limn→∞1n​Hμ​(α0n−1|η)subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓conditional𝛼𝜂subscript→𝑛1𝑛subscript𝐻𝜇conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝛼0𝑛1𝜂\displaystyle h^{u}_{\mu}(f)=h_{\mu}(f,\alpha|\eta)=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}H_{\mu}(\alpha_{0}^{n-1}|\eta) for any α∈𝒫𝛼𝒫\alpha\in{\mathcal{P}} and η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u}.

Lemma 3.2.

(Corollary 3.2 in [6]) For any η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u} subordinate to unstable manifolds and any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0,

hμ​(f|η)=limn→∞−1n​log⁡μxη​(Bnu​(x,ϵ))μ−a.e.​x.subscriptℎ𝜇conditional𝑓𝜂subscript→𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑥𝜂subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑢𝑛𝑥italic-ϵ𝜇a.e.𝑥h_{\mu}(f|\eta)=\lim_{n\to\infty}-\frac{1}{n}\log\mu_{x}^{\eta}(B^{u}_{n}(x,\epsilon))\quad\mu-\text{a.e.}\ x.
Lemma 3.3.

(Proposition 2.14 in [6]) For any α∈𝒫𝛼𝒫\alpha\in{\mathcal{P}} and η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u}, the map μ↦Hμ​(α|η)maps-to𝜇subscript𝐻𝜇conditional𝛼𝜂\mu\mapsto H_{\mu}(\alpha|\eta) from ℳ​(M)ℳ𝑀\mathcal{M}(M) to ℝ+∪{0}superscriptℝ0{\mathbb{R}}^{+}\cup\{0\} is concave.

Furthermore, the map μ↦hμu​(f)maps-to𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}^{u}(f) from ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) to ℝ+∪{0}superscriptℝ0{\mathbb{R}}^{+}\cup\{0\} is affine.

Recall that for each partition α∈𝒫𝛼𝒫\alpha\in{\mathcal{P}}, the partition ζ𝜁\zeta given by ζ​(x)=α​(x)∩Wlocu​(x)𝜁𝑥𝛼𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑢loc𝑥\zeta(x)=\alpha(x)\cap W^{u}_{\mathop{\hbox{\footnotesize\rm loc}}}(x) for any x∈M𝑥𝑀x\in M is denoted by αusuperscript𝛼𝑢\alpha^{u}. Conversely, for each partition η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u}, there is a partition β∈𝒫𝛽𝒫\beta\in{\mathcal{P}} such that η​(x)=β​(x)∩Wlocu​(x)𝜂𝑥𝛽𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑢loc𝑥\eta(x)=\beta(x)\cap W^{u}_{\mathop{\hbox{\footnotesize\rm loc}}}(x) for any x∈M𝑥𝑀x\in M. Denote such β𝛽\beta by ηu̸superscript𝜂italic-u̸\eta^{\not u}.

Lemma 3.4.

(Proposition 2.15 in [6]) (a) Let ν∈ℳ​(M)𝜈ℳ𝑀\nu\in\mathcal{M}(M). For any α∈𝒫𝛼𝒫\alpha\in{\mathcal{P}} and η∈𝒫u𝜂superscript𝒫𝑢\eta\in{\mathcal{P}}^{u} with μ​(∂α)=0𝜇𝛼0\mu(\partial\alpha)=0 and μ​(∂ηu̸)=0𝜇superscript𝜂italic-u̸0\mu(\partial\eta^{\not u})=0, the map μ↦Hμ​(α|η)maps-to𝜇subscript𝐻𝜇conditional𝛼𝜂\mu\mapsto H_{\mu}(\alpha|\eta) from ℳ​(M)ℳ𝑀\mathcal{M}(M) to ℝ+∪{0}superscriptℝ0{\mathbb{R}}^{+}\cup\{0\} is upper semi-continuous at μ𝜇\mu, i.e.

lim supν→μHν​(α|η)≤Hμ​(α|η).subscriptlimit-supremum→𝜈𝜇subscript𝐻𝜈conditional𝛼𝜂subscript𝐻𝜇conditional𝛼𝜂\limsup_{\nu\to\mu}H_{\nu}(\alpha|\eta)\leq H_{\mu}(\alpha|\eta).

(b) The unstable entropy map μ↦hμu​(f)maps-to𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}^{u}(f) from ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) to ℝ+∪{0}superscriptℝ0{\mathbb{R}}^{+}\cup\{0\} is upper semi-continuous at μ𝜇\mu. i.e.

lim supν→μhνu​(f)≤hμu​(f).subscriptlimit-supremum→𝜈𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜈𝑓superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓\limsup_{\nu\to\mu}h^{u}_{\nu}(f)\leq h_{\mu}^{u}(f).

The second part of the above lemma also follows from Theorem D of [20].

3.2. Proof of the variational principle

At first, we prove Proposition 3.6 stated below, which is an easier half of the variational principle Theorem A. The following lemma is well-known.

Lemma 3.5.

Suppose 0≤p1,⋯,pm≤1,s=p1+⋯+pmformulae-sequence0subscript𝑝1⋯formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑚1𝑠subscript𝑝1⋯subscript𝑝𝑚0\leq p_{1},\cdots,p_{m}\leq 1,s=p_{1}+\cdots+p_{m} and a1,⋯,am∈ℝsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑚ℝa_{1},\cdots,a_{m}\in\mathbb{R}. Then

∑i=1mpi​(ai−log⁡pi)≤s​(log​∑i=1meai−log⁡s).superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑒subscript𝑎𝑖𝑠\sum_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}(a_{i}-\log p_{i})\leq s\left(\log\sum_{i=1}^{m}e^{a_{i}}-\log s\right).

The above lemma is almost identical to Lemma 1.24 in [3], except that we have removed the condition s≤1𝑠1s\leq 1.

Proof of Theorem A.

We start to prove that for any ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, there exists μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) such that hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ≥Pu​(f,φ)−ρsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜌h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu\geq P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\rho. Combining with Proposition 3.6, we obtain the first equality in Theorem A.

For some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 small enough, we can find a point x∈M𝑥𝑀x\in M such that

Pu​(f,φ,Wu​(x,δ)¯)≥Pu​(f,φ)−ρ.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜌P^{u}(f,\varphi,\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)})\geq P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\rho.

Take ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 small enough. Let Ensubscript𝐸𝑛E_{n} be an (n,ε)𝑛𝜀(n,\varepsilon) u-separated set of Wu​(x,δ)¯¯superscript𝑊𝑢𝑥𝛿\overline{W^{u}(x,\delta)} with cardinality Nu​(f,ε,n,x,δ)superscript𝑁𝑢𝑓𝜀𝑛𝑥𝛿N^{u}(f,\varepsilon,n,x,\delta) such that

log​∑y∈Enexp⁡((Sn​φ)​(y))≥log⁡Pu​(f,φ,ε,n,x,δ)−1.subscript𝑦subscript𝐸𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑦superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜀𝑛𝑥𝛿1\log\sum_{y\in E_{n}}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(y))\geq\log P^{u}(f,\varphi,\varepsilon,n,x,\delta)-1.

Define

νn:=∑y∈Enexp⁡((Sn​φ)​(y))​δy∑z∈Enexp⁡((Sn​φ)​(z)),assignsubscript𝜈𝑛subscript𝑦subscript𝐸𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑦subscript𝛿𝑦subscript𝑧subscript𝐸𝑛subscript𝑆𝑛𝜑𝑧\nu_{n}:=\frac{\sum_{y\in E_{n}}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(y))\delta_{y}}{\sum_{z\in E_{n}}\exp((S_{n}\varphi)(z))},

and

μn:=1n​∑i=0n−1fi​νn.assignsubscript𝜇𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜈𝑛\mu_{n}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}f^{i}\nu_{n}.

∎

The proof of Corollary A.1 is straightforward, hence is omitted.

Proof of Corollary A.2.

The inequality Pu​(f,φ)≤P​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑃𝑓𝜑P^{u}(f,\varphi)\leq P(f,\varphi) follows from the definition directly.

If f𝑓f is C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha} and there is no positive Lyapunov exponents in the center direction, then by Ledrappier-Young formula [11] and Theorem A in [6], hμ​(f)=hμu​(f)subscriptℎ𝜇𝑓superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓h_{\mu}(f)=h_{\mu}^{u}(f) for any μ∈ℳfe​(M)𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M). Then by Theorem A and the classical variational principle for pressure (cf. Theorem 9.10 in [17]),

Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi) =sup{hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ∈ℳfe​(M)}absentsupremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀\displaystyle=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M)\Big{\}}
=sup{hμ​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ:μ∈ℳfe​(M)}absentsupremumconditional-setsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑒𝑓𝑀\displaystyle=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu:\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{e}_{f}(M)\Big{\}}
=P​(f,φ).absent𝑃𝑓𝜑\displaystyle=P(f,\varphi).

∎

4. U-equilibrium states

In this section, we shall first give some fundamental properties for the set of u-equilibrium states, proving Theorem B. Then for the particular potential φu=−log∥Df|Eu∥\varphi^{u}=-\log\|Df|_{E^{u}}\| we relate the u-equilibrium states at φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u} to the Gibbs u-states of f𝑓f.

4.1. Properties of ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f)

Proof of Theorem B.

It follows from Lemma 3.3 that μ↦hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μmaps-to𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu is affine. Hence (1) holds.

It follows from Lemma 3.4 that μ↦hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μmaps-to𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\mu\mapsto h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu is upper semi-continuous. The set ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) is nonempty because an upper semi-continuous function on a compact space attains its supremum. If μn∈ℳφu​(M,f)subscript𝜇𝑛subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu_{n}\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) and μn→μ→subscript𝜇𝑛𝜇\mu_{n}\to\mu in ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M), then hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ≥lim supn→∞hμnu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μn=Pu​(f,φ)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu\geq\limsup_{n\to\infty}h_{\mu_{n}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{n}=P^{u}(f,\varphi). This together with Theorem A proves that ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) is compact.

If μ∈ℳφu​(M,f)𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) is ergodic, then it is an extreme point of ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) and hence of ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f). Now let μ∈ℳφu​(M,f)𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f) be an extreme point of ℳφu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f), and suppose that μ=p​μ1+(1−p)​μ2𝜇𝑝subscript𝜇11𝑝subscript𝜇2\mu=p\mu_{1}+(1-p)\mu_{2} for some p∈[0,1]𝑝01p\in[0,1]. Combining Lemma 3.3, Pu​(f,φ)=hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ=p​(hμ1u​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ1)+(1−p)​(hμ2u​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ2)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇𝑝superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇1𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇11𝑝superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇2𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇2P^{u}(f,\varphi)=h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu=p(h_{\mu_{1}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{1})+(1-p)(h_{\mu_{2}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{2}). By the variational principle Theorem A, we must have μ1,μ2∈ℳφu​(M,f)subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu_{1},\mu_{2}\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f). Hence μ1=μ2=μsubscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2𝜇\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}=\mu and μ𝜇\mu is an extreme point of ℳf​(M)subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mathcal{M}_{f}(M). Thus μ𝜇\mu is ergodic. This proves (3).

Now we prove (4). By Proposition 2.5 (2), (4) and (6), Pu​(f,φ)=Pu​(f,ψ)+csuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜓𝑐P^{u}(f,\varphi)=P^{u}(f,\psi)+c. On the other hand, it is easy to see that ∫Mφ​𝑑μ=∫Mψ​𝑑μ+csubscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝑐\int_{M}\varphi d\mu=\int_{M}\psi d\mu+c, and hence hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ=hμu​(f)+∫Mψ​𝑑μ+csuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝑐h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu=h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\psi d\mu+c. Thus ℳφu​(M,f)=ℳψu​(M,f)subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜓𝑀𝑓\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f)=\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\psi}(M,f). ∎

4.2. Gibbs u-states

There are two leading cases for a potential φ𝜑\varphi. First, φ𝜑\varphi is the constant function 00. In this case, the unstable topological pressure is just the unstable topological entropy (Proposition 2.5(1)) and Theorem B(2) gives existence of measure of maximal unstable metric entropy.

Second, φu(x):=−log∥detDf|Eu(x)∥\varphi^{u}(x):=-\log\|\mathop{\hbox{{\rm det}}}Df|_{E^{u}}(x)\|. Theorem B(2) gives existence of u-equilibrium states with respect to φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u}. We start to prove Theorem C, which claims that when f𝑓f is C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha} such u-equilibrium states coincide with Gibbs u-states first studied in [12].

Lemma 4.1.

(Cf. Proposition 5.2 in [20]) If f𝑓f is C1+αsuperscript𝐶1𝛼C^{1+\alpha} and μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M), then

hμu​(f)≤∫M−φu​d​μ.subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝜇𝑓subscript𝑀superscript𝜑𝑢𝑑𝜇h^{u}_{\mu}(f)\leq\int_{M}-\varphi^{u}d\mu.

The equality holds if and only if μ𝜇\mu is a Gibbs u-state of f𝑓f.

We characterize Gibbs u-states of f𝑓f by u-equilibrium states of f𝑓f with respect to φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u}:

Proof of Theorem C.

By Theorem A and Lemma 4.1,

Pu​(f,φu)=sup{hμu​(f)+∫Mφu​𝑑μ}=0.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓superscript𝜑𝑢supremumsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀superscript𝜑𝑢differential-d𝜇0P^{u}(f,\varphi^{u})=\sup\Big{\{}h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi^{u}d\mu\Big{\}}=0.

By Lemma 4.1 again, μ𝜇\mu is a Gibbs u-state of f𝑓f if and only if μ𝜇\mu is a u-equilibrium state of φusuperscript𝜑𝑢\varphi^{u}. ∎

Corollary C.1 is already obtained in the proof of Theorem C.

Proof of Corollary C.2.

Since u-equilibrium state for any continuous function φ𝜑\varphi always exists by Theorem B(2), we know from Theorem C that Gibbs u-state always exists. ∎

6. Differentiability properties of the unstable topological pressure

In this section, we consider the differentiability properties of the unstable topological pressure. We shall first give the relation between the u-tangent functionals and the u-equilibrium states, then consider the Gateaux differentiability and Fréchet differentiability of the unstable topological pressure. The equivalence of the Gateaux differentiability of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) and the existence of unique unstable tangent functional Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at a given φ𝜑\varphi is obtained, and several necessary and sufficient conditions for Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) to be Fréchet differentiable at a given φ𝜑\varphi are given.

6.1. U-tangent functionals

Proof of Theorem E.

If μ∈ℳφu​(M,f)𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f), then Pu​(f,φ)=hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇P^{u}(f,\varphi)=h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu. We have

Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi) ≥hμu​(f)+∫M(φ+ψ)​𝑑μ−hμu​(f)−∫Mφ​𝑑μabsentsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑𝜓differential-d𝜇superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\displaystyle\geq h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}(\varphi+\psi)d\mu-h_{\mu}^{u}(f)-\int_{M}\varphi d\mu
=∫Mψ​𝑑μ∀ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)formulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇for-all𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\displaystyle=\int_{M}\psi d\mu\quad\forall\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R})

where the variational principle Theorem A is used in the first inequality. Therefore μ∈tφu​(M,f).𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f).

Conversely, let μ∈tφu​(M,f).𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f). Then for ∀ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)for-all𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\forall\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}),

Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)≥∫Mψ​𝑑μ=∫M(φ+ψ)​𝑑μ−∫Mφ​𝑑μ,superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇subscript𝑀𝜑𝜓differential-d𝜇subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)\geq\int_{M}\psi d\mu=\int_{M}(\varphi+\psi)d\mu-\int_{M}\varphi d\mu,

which implies that

Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−∫M(φ+ψ)​𝑑μ≥Pu​(f,φ)−∫Mφ​𝑑μ.superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓subscript𝑀𝜑𝜓differential-d𝜇superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\displaystyle P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-\int_{M}(\varphi+\psi)d\mu\geq P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\int_{M}\varphi d\mu.

Since ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}) is arbitrary, one has

inf{Pu​(f,h)−∫Mh​𝑑μ:h∈C​(M,ℝ)}≥Pu​(f,φ)−∫Mφ​𝑑μ.infimumconditional-setsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓ℎsubscript𝑀ℎdifferential-d𝜇ℎ𝐶𝑀ℝsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇\displaystyle\inf\Big{\{}P^{u}(f,h)-\int_{M}hd\mu:h\in C(M,\mathbb{R})\Big{\}}\geq P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\int_{M}\varphi d\mu.

By Theorem D(2), we have hμu​(f)≥Pu​(f,φ)−∫Mφ​𝑑μsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇h_{\mu}^{u}(f)\geq P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\int_{M}\varphi d\mu. Combining with the variational principle Theorem A, we have Pu​(f,φ)=hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇P^{u}(f,\varphi)=h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu. Thus μ∈ℳφu​(M,f).𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f). ∎

6.2. Gateaux differentiability

Since Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is convex (Proposition 2.5(5)), for any φ,ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi,\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}) the map t↦1t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ))maps-to𝑡1𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑t\mapsto\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)) is increasing and hence the following two limits exist:

Definition 6.1.
d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ):=limt→0+1t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ))assignsuperscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓subscript→𝑡superscript01𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi):=\lim_{t\to 0^{+}}\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi))

and

d−​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ):=limt→0−1t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)).assignsuperscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓subscript→𝑡superscript01𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑d^{-}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi):=\lim_{t\to 0^{-}}\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)).

The following proposition is immediate.

Proposition 6.2.
  1. (1)

    d−​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)=−d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(−ψ)superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓d^{-}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)=-d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(-\psi),

  2. (2)

    d−​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)≤d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓d^{-}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)\leq d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi).

Recall that the unstable topological pressure Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is said to be Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if

limt→01t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ))subscript→𝑡01𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi))

exists for any ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}) (See Definition 1.6). By Proposition 6.2, Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if and only if for any ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R})

d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)=−d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(−ψ).superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)=-d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(-\psi).
Lemma 6.3.

For φ,ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜑𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\varphi,\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}), d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)=sup{∫Mψ​𝑑μ:μ∈tφu​(M,f)}.superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓supremumconditional-setsubscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)=\sup\{\int_{M}\psi d\mu:\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f)\}.

Proof.

If μ∈tφu​(M,f)𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f), then ∫Mψ​𝑑μ≤1t​(Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ))subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇1𝑡superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\int_{M}\psi d\mu\leq\frac{1}{t}(P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)) for ∀t>0for-all𝑡0\forall t>0. So ∫Mψ​𝑑μ≤d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ).subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓\int_{M}\psi d\mu\leq d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi).

Conversely, let a=d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)𝑎superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓a=d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi). Define a linear functional γ𝛾\gamma on {t​ψ:t∈ℝ}conditional-set𝑡𝜓𝑡ℝ\{t\psi:t\in\mathbb{R}\} by γ​(t​ψ)=t​a𝛾𝑡𝜓𝑡𝑎\gamma(t\psi)=ta. By the convexity of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot), γ​(t​ψ)=t​a≤Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ).𝛾𝑡𝜓𝑡𝑎superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\gamma(t\psi)=ta\leq P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi). Using Hahn-Banach theorem, γ𝛾\gamma can be extended to a linear functional on C​(M,ℝ)𝐶𝑀ℝC(M,\mathbb{R}) such that

γ​(h)≤Pu​(f,φ+h)−Pu​(f,φ).𝛾ℎsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑ℎsuperscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑\gamma(h)\leq P^{u}(f,\varphi+h)-P^{u}(f,\varphi).

By Riesz representation theorem, there exists μ∈tφu​(M,f)𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f) such that

∫Mψ​𝑑μ=γ​(ψ)=a=d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ).subscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝛾𝜓𝑎superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓\int_{M}\psi d\mu=\gamma(\psi)=a=d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi).

∎

Proof of Theorem F.

If Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi, then for any ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}),

d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)=−d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(−ψ).superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)=-d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(-\psi).

By Lemma 6.3, we have for any ψ∈C​(M,ℝ)𝜓𝐶𝑀ℝ\psi\in C(M,\mathbb{R}),

sup{∫Mψ​𝑑μ:μ∈tφu​(M,f)}supremumconditional-setsubscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\displaystyle\sup\left\{\int_{M}\psi d\mu:\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f)\right\} =−sup{∫M(−ψ)​𝑑μ:μ∈tφu​(M,f)}absentsupremumconditional-setsubscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\displaystyle=-\sup\left\{\int_{M}(-\psi)d\mu:\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f)\right\}
=inf{∫Mψ​𝑑μ:μ∈tφu​(M,f)}.absentinfimumconditional-setsubscript𝑀𝜓differential-d𝜇𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\displaystyle=\inf\left\{\int_{M}\psi d\mu:\mu\in t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f)\right\}.

It follows that tφu​(M,f)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f) consists of a single element μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi}.

Conversely, suppose that tφu​(M,f)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f) consists of a single element μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi}. Then by Lemma 6.3

d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(ψ)=∫Mψ​𝑑μφ=−∫M(−ψ)​𝑑μφ=−d+​Pu​(f,φ)​(−ψ).superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓subscript𝑀𝜓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝜑subscript𝑀𝜓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝜑superscript𝑑superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(\psi)=\int_{M}\psi d\mu_{\varphi}=-\int_{M}(-\psi)d\mu_{\varphi}=-d^{+}P^{u}(f,\varphi)(-\psi).

So Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi. ∎

Corollary F.1 follows directly from Theorems E and F.

6.3. Fréchet differentiability

Lemma 6.4.

Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) has a unique u-tangent functional at φ𝜑\varphi if and only if there is a unique measure μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} such that whenever (μn)⊂ℳf​(M)subscript𝜇𝑛subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀(\mu_{n})\subset\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) with hμnu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μn→Pu​(f,φ)→superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu_{n}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{n}\to P^{u}(f,\varphi) we have μn→μφ→subscript𝜇𝑛subscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{n}\to\mu_{\varphi} as n→∞.→𝑛n\to\infty.

Proof.

If hμnu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μn→Pu​(f,φ)→superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu_{n}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{n}\to P^{u}(f,\varphi) and μn→μ→subscript𝜇𝑛𝜇\mu_{n}\to\mu for some μ∈ℳf​(M)𝜇subscriptℳ𝑓𝑀\mu\in\mathcal{M}_{f}(M) as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty, by the upper semi-continuity of unstable entropy map, we have

hμu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μ=Pu​(f,φ).superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-d𝜇superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu=P^{u}(f,\varphi).

Namely, μ∈ℳφu​(M,f)=tφu​(M,f).𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℳ𝑢𝜑𝑀𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑡𝜑𝑢𝑀𝑓\mu\in\mathcal{M}^{u}_{\varphi}(M,f)=t_{\varphi}^{u}(M,f). Hence there is only one such measure μ𝜇\mu which is denoted by μφ.subscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi}. This finishes the proof for the “only if” part.

For“if” part, let μ𝜇\mu be a u-tangent functional to Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi. Note that such μ𝜇\mu exists by Theorem E and Theorem B(2). Put μn=μsubscript𝜇𝑛𝜇\mu_{n}=\mu. Then hμnu​(f)+∫Mφ​𝑑μn→Pu​(f,φ)→superscriptsubscriptℎsubscript𝜇𝑛𝑢𝑓subscript𝑀𝜑differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑛superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑h_{\mu_{n}}^{u}(f)+\int_{M}\varphi d\mu_{n}\to P^{u}(f,\varphi). Thus μ=μφ𝜇subscript𝜇𝜑\mu=\mu_{\varphi}. It follows that μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} is the unique u-tangent functional of Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi. ∎

Recall that Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is called Fréchet differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi if ∃γ∈C​(M,ℝ)∗𝛾𝐶superscript𝑀ℝ\exists\gamma\in C(M,\mathbb{R})^{*} such that

limψ→0|Pu​(f,φ+ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)−γ​(ψ)|‖ψ‖=0subscript→𝜓0superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝛾𝜓norm𝜓0\lim_{\psi\to 0}\frac{|P^{u}(f,\varphi+\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)-\gamma(\psi)|}{\|\psi\|}=0

(see Definition 1.7). If Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Fréchet differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi, then

limt→0|Pu​(f,φ+t​ψ)−Pu​(f,φ)−t​γ​(ψ)|t​‖ψ‖=0.subscript→𝑡0superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝜓superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓𝜑𝑡𝛾𝜓𝑡norm𝜓0\lim_{t\to 0}\frac{|P^{u}(f,\varphi+t\psi)-P^{u}(f,\varphi)-t\gamma(\psi)|}{t\|\psi\|}=0.

Thus Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) is Gateaux differentiable at φ𝜑\varphi. Moreover, γ​(ψ)=∫Mψ​𝑑μφ𝛾𝜓subscript𝑀𝜓differential-dsubscript𝜇𝜑\gamma(\psi)=\int_{M}\psi d\mu_{\varphi} where μφsubscript𝜇𝜑\mu_{\varphi} is the unique u-tangent functional to Pu​(f,⋅)superscript𝑃𝑢𝑓⋅P^{u}(f,\cdot) at φ𝜑\varphi by Theorem F and Lemma 6.3.

Proof of Theorem G.
